title: Inside the Winter White House: Exclusive holiday snaps with Donald and Melania Trump are now the ultimate status symbol for wealthy Americans
text:
Inside the Winter White House: Exclusive holiday snaps with Donald and Melania Trump are now the ultimate status symbol for wealthy Americans A holiday in the 'heart of Government' is now the ultimate status symbol Credit: Instagram/johnclayreed Helena Horton  13am 
U S citizens with the means to pay now have the chance of unprecedented access to the First Couple. For a price, members of the exclusive Mar-a-Lago club, now known as the 'Winter White House' might find themselves sitting across from Melania Trump at breakfast, taking a sun-soaked selfie with the President at Happy Hour and some guests have even witnessed him at work as he took part in a security briefing over dinner on the patio. 
From the recent social media posts of members, it appears taking a holiday in the 'heart of Government' is now the ultimate status symbol, as they tag their pictures #WinterWhiteHouse and try to get a selfie with members of the First Family. 
Membership of the exclusive club - which reportedly has a hefty initiation fee of $200,000 - has the bonus of a sighting and perhaps even a selfie with the First Family, as President Trump has been there two out of the three weekends he has been in office. Security briefings as dinnertime entertainment Security briefings are now dinnertime entertainment Credit: Facebook 
R elaxed holidaymakers have uploaded images of Donald Trump and his security team having a briefing, almost as if it were dinner entertainment. 
Richard DeAgazio wrote on Facebook: "Holy Moly! It was fascinating to watch the flurry of activity at dinner when the news came that North Korea had launched a missile in the direction of Japan. 
"The Prime Minister Abe of Japan huddles with his staff and the President is on the phone with Washington D.C. The two world leaders conferred and then went into another room for a hastily arranged press conference. 
"Wow...The center of the action!" Breakfast with the First Lady Feb 11, 2017 at 1:35pm PST 
V isitors breakfasting at the exclusive club can have a full view of members of the First Family. 
Pictured is Melania Trump, in the post proudly displayed on Instagram. Selfies with Donald Trump 
It appears the President is happy to take pictures with his paying guests. 
Appearing to play 'spot the President', members of the club are seen posing with him at a wedding and during Happy Hour on the golf course. A post shared by John Reed (@johnclayreed) on Feb 12, 2017 at 6:24pm PST A post shared by valeriemarion (@valeriemarion) on Feb 12, 2017 at 9:51am PST 
O ne holidaymaker wrote: "Sharing this fairytale with my girlfriends!!" and informed her followers she was having a post-golf Happy Hour 'pre-game' with the President. Watch | Trump appears to crash wedding after North Korea missile statement 00:52 Partying with the President 
A fter a sun-soaked day on the golf course or by the pool, guests don their finery and go to one of many of the galas and balls held at the club. 
President Trump hasn't let his busy schedule as a world leader stop him from attending multiple events at Mar-a-Lago. 
Guests are pictured below proudly spotting the First Couple, and some even managed to get a selfie with them. A post shared by Amy (@amypnyc) on Feb 11, 2017 at 9:49pm PST A post shared by Chase Thomas (@1chaseyourdreams) on Feb 5, 2017 at 11:16am PST A post shared by Mark Simone (@marksimoneny) on Feb 5, 2017 at 5:47pm PST A post shared by Abigail (Abbey) Bauman (@abbeybauman22) on Feb 6, 2017 at 8:39pm PST The access to the First Family has caused criticism 
C ritics have pointed to the national security threat posed by the easy access many have to the President and First Lady. 
Chelsea Clinton asked: "How many of Mar-a-Lago’s new members will be (already are?) members of foreign intelligence agencies and media organisations?" 
CNN and the Guardian have both raised concerns about the fact the President entertained the Japanese Prime Minister at the club. 
However, Team Trump has dismissed all talk of threats to national security. 
In an interview with the New York Time s, Eric Trump compared it to George W Bush’s use of his Crawford, Texas ranch, and added that the use of the club to entertain foreign leaders could be an asset for the country. 
He said: “If he could do that with Putin ... and he can make them friends and they can have trust in one another, he just did something that not many presidents have been able to do.”
